feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 02 at 1:42PM AKDT until April 03 at 6:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM AKDT SUNDAY... ...BLIZZARD WARNING IS CANCELLED... * WHAT...Blowing snow expected. Plan on areas of poor visibilities and difficult travel conditions at times. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph will cause areas of blowing and drifting snow. * WHERE...Western Arctic Coast especially near Point Lay.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 02 at 3:24PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Breezy Sunday With Stronger Winds Monday... A series of disturbances will bring increased breezes Sunday afternoon and evening, with stronger winds Monday afternoon and evening. For Sunday, westerly gusts of 20 to 30 mph with around 35 mph in wind prone locations, is expected. For Monday, there is potential for westerly gusts of 35 to 45 mph, with gusts 45 to 60

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 03 at 2:32AM EDT until April 04 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK NOW IN EFFECT THROUGH MONDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Dangerous rip currents. * WHERE...Walton, Bay, Gulf, and Franklin County Beaches. * WHEN...Through Monday morning. * IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 02 at 11:17PM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: Areas of dense fog have developed across the Suwannee Valley and this fog is expected to expand eastward toward the Highway 301 corridor over the next couple of hours. The nature of the fog is such that visibilities will vary greatly over short distances. If driving, slow down and leave extra distance ahead of you in case a sudden stop is needed.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 02 at 4:01PM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Patchy frost possible in Sheltered Valleys early Sunday Morning... Widespread low temperatures of 34 to 39 are expected early Sunday morning. A few 33 degree readings are possible in the coldest hollows. This will be cold enough for patchy light frost in the typically coldest locations. If you have frost-sensitive vegetation, consider providing protection to avoid possible

entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Columbia River Gorge of Washington; Foothills of the Blue Mountains of Washington; Kittitas Valley; Lower Columbia Basin of Washington; Simcoe Highlands; Yakima Valley

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued April 02 at 3:02PM PDT until April 05 at 11:00AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY MORNING THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING ABOVE 2500 FEET... * WHAT...Heavy snow possible above 2500 feet. Total snow accumulations of 12 to 24 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph on Monday and Monday night. * WHERE...East Slopes of the Washington Cascades.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Slopes of the Washington Cascades

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued April 02 at 2:30PM PDT until April 05 at 11:00AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...LATE SEASON WINTER STORM TO DELIVER HEAVY SNOW TO THE CASCADE CREST... .Snow will increase Sunday evening and become heavy at times into Monday. Snow over the Cascade crest will continue to accumulate through Monday night into Tuesday morning. Winter travel conditions will be likely along Highway 2 from Coles Corner to Stevens Pass.

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued April 02 at 2:16PM PDT until April 04 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued April 02 at 2:06PM PDT until April 04 at 6:00PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT FOR LATE TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Sneaker waves possible. High surf conditions possible for Monday through Tuesday morning. * WHERE...In Oregon, North Oregon Coast and Central Oregon Coast. In Washington, South Washington Coast.

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued April 02 at 12:29PM PDT until April 04 at 8:00AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH WIND WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY EVENING THROUGH MONDAY MORNING NEAR BEACHES AND HEADLANDS... * WHAT...Southwest winds 30 to 40 mph with gusts between 50 to 60 mph possible near beaches and headlands. * WHERE...In Oregon, North Oregon Coast. In Washington, South Washington Coast.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued April 02 at 12:24PM PDT until April 05 at 5:00AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH LATE MONDAY NIGHT FOR THE SOUTH WASHINGTON CASCADES ABOVE 3500 FEET... * WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 8 to 16 inches near 4000 feet with 16 to 32 inches above 5000 feet. Winds could gust as high as 50 mph with even stronger winds

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 02 at 11:04AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...THREAT OF RIVER FLOODING MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY MORNING FOR KING COUNTY... A couple of frontal systems will bring rain, heavy at times, Sunday afternoon through Monday night. Rivers will respond with sharp rises. Rainfall totals of 3-5 inches are likely for the central Cascades for this period. This could cause the Snoqualmie River in

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 02 at 10:55AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY EVENING THROUGH TUESDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible. * WHERE...A portion of northwest Washington, including the following county, Mason. * WHEN...From Sunday evening through Tuesday afternoon.
